tweets.text: AbolishTheEU

quoted.text:
üá™üá∫ WELCOME TO THE EU'S BUREAUCRATIC EMPIRE: WHERE DEMOCRACY GOES TO DIE

So, you went to the polls. You voted. Maybe you even knocked doors or argued politics with your uncle over dinner. Congratulations. You exercised your democratic right. Now let‚Äôs tell you why it doesn‚Äôt matter.

Because in the grand, gleaming halls of Brussels, someone you didn‚Äôt elect is making the real decisions. And that‚Äôs not a conspiracy - it‚Äôs the institutional design.

This is the EU: a glorious experiment in post-democratic governance. The elected leaders of your country? They get to give speeches, sure. But when it comes to setting the rules, managing trade, telling your judges what to rule and your farmers what to grow - there‚Äôs a lovely little pyramid, and guess what? You‚Äôre not anywhere near the top.

And no, the European Parliament doesn‚Äôt save you. It‚Äôs the decorative plant of EU democracy. The laws don‚Äôt start there. The real power sits with the European Commission - an unelected gang of technocrats who can outregulate, outmaneuver, and outvote your national government on everything from fisheries to fiscal policy. You can‚Äôt fire them. You can‚Äôt replace them. But don‚Äôt worry - they‚Äôre very ‚Äúcompetent.‚Äù

This is how democracy dies: not with tanks, but with treaties. Slowly. Softly. Signed away by prime ministers chasing subsidies and photo-ops. Until one day, your country‚Äôs parliament becomes a glorified comment section on rules already written elsewhere.

Try passing a law your voters want that conflicts with EU policy. Try setting an immigration standard your people demanded. Good luck. You‚Äôll be politely reminded that you‚Äôre bound by commitments - commitments no voter ever saw on a ballot. And if you push too hard? Out come the infringement procedures. Out come the threats. Out come the lectures about ‚ÄúEuropean values,‚Äù as if bureaucracy is a moral compass.

And don‚Äôt you dare try to question the EU‚Äôs authority. That‚Äôs what ‚Äúpopulists‚Äù do. That‚Äôs dangerous. That‚Äôs the kind of thinking that leads to... horror of horrors... sovereignty.

Because at the end of the day, this isn‚Äôt just about cooperation. This is about control. This is about centralizing power behind a wall of civil servants and calling it progress. It‚Äôs about wrapping political decisions in technocratic jargon until nobody remembers who was supposed to be in charge.

You still get to vote, sure. But the question is: for what? National elections start to feel like choosing the flavor of frosting on a cake someone else already baked. With someone else‚Äôs recipe. And someone else‚Äôs rules about how many eggs you‚Äôre allowed to use.

Call it what you want - shared governance, interdependence, modern integration. But don‚Äôt pretend it‚Äôs democratic. When your vote can‚Äôt change the law, when your government can‚Äôt defy the script, and when real power belongs to the unelected, then what you‚Äôve got isn‚Äôt democracy.

It‚Äôs bureaucracy with a flag.

tweets.text: Precisely

quoted.text: My recent trip to Brussels for the @NATO Ministerial meeting left me with one overriding impression: the US has long failed to address the glaring inconsistency between its relations with NATO and the EU. These are almost all the same countries in both organizations. When these countries wear their NATO hats, they insist that Transatlantic cooperation is the cornerstone of our mutual security. But when these countries wear their EU hats, they pursue all sorts of agendas that are often utterly adverse to US interests and security‚Äîincluding censorship, economic suicide/climate fanaticism, open borders, disdain for national sovereignty/promotion of multilateral governance and taxation, support for Communist Cuba, etc etc. This inconsistency cannot continue. Either the great nations of Europe are our partners in protecting the Western civilization that we inherited from them or they are not. But we cannot pretend that we are partners while those nations allow the EU‚Äôs unelected, undemocratic, and unrepresentative bureaucracy in Brussels to pursue policies of civilizational suicide.

tweets.text:
The South African government is super racist against anyone who isn‚Äôt Black.

Just a fact. It‚Äôs literally in the laws.

quoted.text:
Isn‚Äôt it ironic how Elon‚Äôs Starlink wants to drop free, unlimited, super-fast internet into 5,000 rural South African schools, but SA‚Äôs bureaucracy insists on saying no.

I think the 2.4 million kids in SA without proper access would benefit immensely.  Starlink is even putting R500 million (about $29.4 million USD) on the table themselves, no cost to the government or the schools.
All they‚Äôre asking? A normal licence to operate in SA.

Here‚Äôs the crazy part: because of the 30% black-ownership rule (B-BBEE), ICASA keeps saying ‚Äúnope.‚Äù

Starlink says, ‚ÄúCool, we won‚Äôt sell shares, but we‚Äôll just give you this giant school project instead,‚Äù using the same Equity Equivalent programme that Microsoft, Amazon and IBM already got approved with.

The Communications Minister is literally begging ICASA to accept it. Neighbours like Botswana, Zimbabwe and Mozambique are already connected and loving it.

Yet here we are, end of 2025, and those satellites are just flying over South Africa doing nothing while kids in the bundus still can‚Äôt pursue their dreams.

Come on, South Africa, don‚Äôt be the only country turning down free internet for millions of learners. 
The irony, to me, is that Elon was born in South Africa, the very place that is telling him no to such a generopus offer!

GROK SAVES A MAN‚ÄôS LIFE AFTER ER MISSES NEAR-RUPTURED APPENDIX

A 49-year-old man says Grok, the AI built by Elon‚Äôs xAI, saved his life after an ER doctor misdiagnosed a near-ruptured appendix as acid reflux and sent him home.

In agony for 24 hours, the man turned to Grok for help. 

After listing his symptoms, the AI flagged a ‚Äúperforated ulcer or atypical appendicitis‚Äù and told him to go back immediately and demand a CT scan.

He copied Grok‚Äôs reasoning, returned to the hospital, insisted on the scan, and doctors found an inflamed appendix on the verge of rupture. 

Six hours later, it was removed, and the man woke up laughing under anesthesia, pain-free.

He later revealed he didn‚Äôt tell doctors that Grok had advised him, claiming instead that ‚Äúhis sister, a nurse,‚Äù had urged the test, worried they‚Äôd ignore AI input.

The post went viral, with users calling Grok‚Äôs intervention proof that AI can spot what overworked doctors miss. 

Some even said they‚Äôd ‚Äúwelcome AI doctors if it meant better care.‚Äù

Elon has long predicted AI-powered medicine would arrive before most expect.
